title: ChatGPT’s inconsistent moral advice influences users’ judgment - Scientific Reports

last_post.content:
My first thought: We need a paper about what ChatGPT does with the trolley problem like a hole in the head.

My second thought—and don't confuse this for an endorsement of the paper—was much darker: we probably DO need work on this, and on how humans are influenced by it. The latter is the primary of the subject of the paper.

I was going to complain about how I think the authors rather naively talk about an LLM's moral stance as if such a thing could exist, but...

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-023-31341-0

title: Six Centuries of Type & Printing (letterpress and ebook bundle)

last_post.content: Back in 2020, I published Six Centuries of Type & Printing, a concise book – 64 pages – that actually starts centuries before Gutenberg, with Chinese and Korea printing, and then digs into 1450 to 2020, covering ~600 years of technological advances. Set in hot-metal type (Monotype Bembo) in North Yorkshire, printed in London, and bound in Germany with a foil-stamped cover & slipcase, I still have copies available for shipping worldwide! https://glog.glennf.com/tiny-type-museum-time-capsule-and-more/six-centuries-letterpress (ebook edition available)

title: Big business and government are adopting artificial intelligence, what can it do for the rest of us? - Flux

last_post.content:
Thread: #AI and the rest of us

This is a summary of the two most recent episodes of my podcast Theory of Change which look at how artificial intelligence will impact regular people, and how to use it for own benefit.

As @simon notes, AI has problems, but it can also be useful for 𝘺𝘰𝘶.

https://flux.community/matthew-sheffield/2023/04/big-business-and-government-are-adopting-artificial-intelligence-what-can-it-do-for-the-rest-of-us/

👉🏼 „Saying Goodbye to GitHub | Ersei 'n Stuff”
🔗https://ersei.net/en/blog/bye-bye-github
💬 …you too can get programming help with no obligation to give back to anyone!
Harsh words, but good discussion points. Personally I don't think Copilot breeds more lurkers, they are a general problem.

Inspired by Cory Doctorow (@pluralistic) , I've been thinking about the IndieWeb idea of POSSE (Publish on your Own Site, Syndicate Elsewhere, see https://indieweb.org/POSSE) and how to extend the reach of my blog posts. So I'm trying something new and syndicating blog posts to dev.to.

dev.to makes this quite nice with native support a "canonical URL" for posts originally published elsewhere. It's also pretty easy to repost existing content to since it supports Markdown (my posts are written in reStructuredText for my website but can be easily converted to Markdown using pandoc) and future posts can be automatically shared to dev.to via an RSS feed.

So, assuming I don't find any reason to cancel this experiment, you'll be able to read my writing at https://dev.to/pbarker as well as here on Mastodon and on my website.

(originally posted at https://pbarker.dev/posts/2023-04-10/syndication/)

#writing #blog #blogging #indieweb

The third report on the R-spatial evolution project has been published. It links back to earlier blogs and presentations, and focusses on work that maintainers of R packages and workflows using rgdal, rgeos and maptools need to put in train now. The first changes will occur in June 2023, and the retiring packages will be archived during October 2023. If you are giving a workshop or tutorial during the Northern hemisphere summer, aim for June. #rspatial

title: United States v. American Tel. and Tel. Co., 552 F. Supp. 131 (D.D.C. 1983)

last_post.content:
While we're talking telephones, I recently re-read the 1982 "Modification of Final Judgement" that broke up the Bell System into separate local and long distance companies, changing the landscape of US telecom forever.

Aside from the huge impact of the case itself, the opinion is a fascinating history, especially for the significant role Bell Labs played in shaping Judge Greene's rulings.

Long, but richly repays a careful reading. https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/FSupp/552/131/1525975/

Mathematician and aerospace engineer Mary Jackson was born #OTD in 1921. She worked at the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics until it was succeeded by NASA in 1958. Jackson then became the first Black woman to work as a NASA engineer.

Bio: https://www.nasa.gov/content/mary-w-jackson-biography

title: What Happened When DataCamp Tried To Cover Up Its CEO’s Sexual Misconduct

last_post.content: Five years later, I still occasionally get pokes on LinkedIn saying, "Hey, you used to work at DataCamp, what can you tell me about them?" My response is, "Their CEO committed sexual assault, they tried to bury the story, he finally stepped aside after an outcry but returned while everyone was distracted by COVID." See https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/daveyalba/datacamp-sexual-harassment-metoo-tech-startup for @daveyalba's excellent summary from 2019 and https://third-bit.com/2019/04/15/an-exchange-with-datacamp/ for a personal addendum.

This course on parallel programming by @JukkaSuomela at Aalto is absolutely fantastic:
https://ppc.cs.aalto.fi/
It covers everything: how the hardware works, thread based parallelism, pipelining, vectorization, even GPU programming! The lecture notes are super clear and detailed.

title: Hashtags are everything on Mastodon — why not give them a home?

last_post.content:
I agree with @thedextriarchy. Shoving as many hashtags into a Mastodon post feels like spam.

Unfortunately, if you want to be discovered on Mastodon, that’s what you got to do.

This Verge article suggests that removing hashtags from the post body could be a solution (à la Tumblr).

But there’s an easier solution: allow full text search.

Almost every other Fediverse service allows this, including Akkoma, Calckey, Friendica, etc.

https://www.theverge.com/23673125/mastodon-separate-tags-hashtag-navigation-accessibility

@fediversenews

There are a lot of words in his article dancing around what I think is a simple, obvious dilemma for the GOP:

🔹 The GOP base wants hard-core Trump-Kari Lake candidates.

🔹The general electorate doesn't.

So the candidates who win GOP primaries are likely to lose in general elections.

The problem gets worse for the GOP with each election cycle as the electorate grows more diverse, and more of the generation that came to the polls in Wisconsin are eligible to vote.
